title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus ecological stoichiometry ofPhragmites australiswetlands in different reaches in Minjiang River estuary
abstract: Ecological stoichiometry is the study of the balance of energy and multiple chemical elements.Generally,this perspective examines the causes and consequences of elemental imbalances between resources,producers,and consumers in the environment.C,N and P are key elements controlling organism growth.However,the relative needs of the elements are poorly quantified,and dependencies between elements are not well investigated.These three elements are strongly coupled in their biochemical functioning.Furthermore,the ecological stoichiometry of C,N and P is the indication for organic carbon decomposition and nutrition limit. The element ratios in wetlands,especially for the estuarine wetlands,appear to be more variable than other ecosystems worldwide.Moreover,the studies on soil C,N and P stoichiometry have not been thoroughly studied.In fact,soil as the carrier of organisms and elements plays very important roles.Therefore,studies on C,N and P ecological stoichiometry of wetland soils will be favorable to clarify the available of nutrition and the cycle and balance of C,N and P. An amount of approximately 18,000 km of coastline in China is covered by an estimated 12,000 km2 of tidal estuary wetlands.These tidal wetlands are generally rich in animal and plant biodiversity and appear to have important biogeochemical roles within the entire estuary ecosystem.One of these important tidal wetland ecosystems is found within the Minjiang River estuary in southeast China,which is located at the transition of mid-and southern subtropical climate zones in China. Phragmites australis is the dominant species in Minjiang River estuarine wetland and distributes everywhere from upper reach to lower river.Here we chose the Youxizhou wetland,Bianfuzhou wetland and Shanyutan wetland as the study areas and examined the ecological stoichiometric characteristics of wetland soils in different river reaches and their indication.In upper reach,the values of soil C/N,C/P,N/P(0—60 cm) of P.australis wetland were 36.5—51.3,43.0—93.6 and 0.8—2.3,with averages of 44.1,66.9 and 1.6,respectively.In middle reach,the values of soil C/N,C/P,N/P(0—60 cm) were 15.8—21.7,28.0—72.2 and 1.6—4.2,with averages of 17.6,45.7 and 2.6,respectively.In lower reach,the values of soil C/N,C/P,N/P(0—60 cm) were 13.5—19.8,63.6—125.4 and 4.2—6.3,with averages of 16.4,90.5 and 5.5,respectively.C/N,C/P and N/P ratios appeared various tendencies among wetlands in different reaches.Soil C/N ratios were in the order of upper reachmiddle reachlower reach,C/P ratios were in the order of lower river upper rivermiddle river,while N/P ratios were in the order of lower reachmiddle reachupper reach.The variation of C/N,C/P,N/P ratios in soil profile of single reach was smaller than that among different reaches.Soil water and silt contents were the key factors controlling the change of C/N,C/P,N/P ratios of wetland soils in different reaches.Soil C/N and N/P ratios were preferable indication for anaerobic carbon decomposition.

motivations: The balance of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus in wetland ecosystems is poorly understood, despite their importance for organism growth and ecosystem functioning.
There is a need to investigate the ecological stoichiometry of C, N, and P in wetland soils to clarify nutrient availability and cycling.
objectives: Examine the ecological stoichiometric characteristics of wetland soils in different river reaches of the Minjiang River estuary.
Investigate the variation of C/N, C/P, and N/P ratios in soil profiles of Phragmites australis wetlands.
Identify the key factors controlling the change of C/N, C/P, and N/P ratios in wetland soils.
methods: Select three study areas (Youxizhou, Bianfuzhou, and Shanyutan wetlands) in the Minjiang River estuary.
Measure the values of soil C/N, C/P, and N/P ratios at different depths (0-60 cm) in each study area.
Analyze the variation of C/N, C/P, and N/P ratios among different reaches and soil profiles.
results: C/N, C/P, and N/P ratios varied among wetlands in different reaches, with distinct tendencies.
Soil water and silt contents were identified as key factors controlling the change of C/N, C/P, and N/P ratios.
Soil C/N and N/P ratios were found to be indicative of anaerobic carbon decomposition.
llama_json.research_subject: Ecological stoichiometry of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus in Phragmites australis wetlands

motivations: The relative needs and dependencies between key elements controlling organism growth, such as carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus, are poorly quantified and not well investigated.

The ecological stoichiometry of these elements, which is indicative of organic carbon decomposition and nutrition limit, is more variable in estuarine wetlands than in other ecosystems and has not been thoroughly studied.
Understanding the ecological stoichiometry of wetland soils is crucial for clarifying the availability of nutrition and the cycle and balance of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus.
objectives: Examine the ecological stoichiometric characteristics of wetland soils in different river reaches in the Minjiang River estuary.
Investigate the variation of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus ratios in soil profiles of different reaches and identify the key factors controlling these changes.
Assess the potential of soil carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus ratios as indicators for anaerobic carbon decomposition.
methods: Study the ecological stoichiometry of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus in the soils of Phragmites australis wetlands in different reaches of the Minjiang River estuary.
Measure and compare the carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus ratios in the soil profiles of different reaches.
Analyze the influence of soil water and silt contents on the changes in carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus ratios.
results: Identify the variation in carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus ratios among wetlands in different river reaches.
Determine the key factors, such as soil water and silt contents, controlling the change of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus ratios in wetland soils.
Establish the potential of soil carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus ratios as indicators for anaerobic carbon decomposition.
openai_json.research_subject: Ecological stoichiometry of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus in Phragmites australis wetlands in the Minjiang River estuary

motivations: The ecological stoichiometry of C, N and P in wetland soils, particularly in estuarine wetlands, is poorly understood despite its importance for nutrient cycling and organic carbon decomposition.
Element ratios in wetlands are more variable than in other ecosystems, and the dependencies between C, N and P elements in soil systems require better quantification.
objectives: Examine the ecological stoichiometric characteristics of C, N and P in Phragmites australis wetland soils across different reaches of the Minjiang River estuary.
Identify the key factors controlling the variation of C/N, C/P and N/P ratios in wetland soils and their indication for nutrient availability and carbon decomposition.
methods: Analyze soil samples from three wetland sites (Youxizhou, Bianfuzhou, and Shanyutan) representing upper, middle, and lower reaches of the Minjiang River estuary.
Measure C, N and P concentrations and calculate their stoichiometric ratios in soil profiles.
Examine relationships between stoichiometric ratios and environmental factors such as soil water and silt contents.
results: Soil C/N ratios decreased from upper to lower reaches, C/P ratios were highest in lower reaches, and N/P ratios increased from upper to lower reaches.
Soil water and silt contents were identified as key factors controlling the variation of stoichiometric ratios across different reaches.
Soil C/N and N/P ratios serve as effective indicators for anaerobic carbon decomposition in wetland soils.
